awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Medium: Reconfigurable Antennas and Optimized Multi-channel MIMO Designs for DSA Systems with a Broad Frequency Coverage
awd_abstract_narration:
Dominated by mobile video traffic, the exponential growth of wireless data is placing severe demand on the radio frequence (RF) spectrum. The role of spectrum as a critical economic growth engine was recently highlighted in the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (PCAST) report, which recommended creating 'the first shared-use spectrum superhighways.' The FCC has set in motion several initiatives that aim at identifying underutilized portions of the licensed spectrum and exploring new models for spectrum sharing among different types of users. In this project, the PIs propose to address the feasibility of dynamic spectrum access (DSA) operation over a large swath of the spectrum, encompassing the UHF portion of the TV White Spaces (470-698 MHz segment), the 3.5 GHz radar band, as well as other bands in the 1 to 4.4 GHz range that may later become candidates for DSA operation. If successful, this project is expected to have a transformational impact on many wireless communication systems, including extended-range wireless LANs, regional wireless area networks, wireless sensor systems, and coexisting cellular/WLAN systems (e.g., LTE-U and WiFi).

The research agenda includes novel designs for a small form-factor reconfigurable antenna element that can operate over this frequency range, advanced antenna-circuit configurations for tunable narrowband carrier aggregation in the UHF TVWS segment, antenna configurations for supporting polarization diversity in MIMO-based DSA, optimized price-based cognitive MIMO (CMIMO) precoders that are founded in game theoretic techniques, and scheduling mechanisms for network-wide CMIMO operation. Optimizations at both the signal level (via MIMO precoding matrices) as well as the antenna level (via highly tunable small form-factor reconfigurable antennas) will be performed. The project also includes a comprehensive educational plan to further broaden its impact, including integrating research with undergraduate and graduate education, recruiting and outreach to minority and under-represented students, Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REUs), disseminating research data and findings through open access, and outreach to society through open-lab days and other activities.

NeTS: Medium: Reconfigurable Antennas and Optimized Multi-channel MIMO Designs for DSA Systems with a Broad Frequency Coverage

Award #: CNS – 1513649

Investigators: Marwan Krunz (PI) and Hao Xin (Co-PI)

Outcomes Report

December 2020

 

The main goal of this project was to enable dynamic spectrum access (DSA) over a large swath of the spectrum, encompassing the UHF portion of the TV White Spaces (470-698 MHz), the 3.5 GHz radar band, as well as other bands in the 1 to 4.4 GHz range that are candidates for DSA operation. Achieving such a lofty goal can have a transformational impact on wireless systems, allowing RF devices to hop dynamically between bands so as to achieve agile communications and mitigate interference and network congestion. The project’s outcomes included novel designs for  small form-factor reconfigurable antennas that can operate over a broad frequency range, advanced antenna-circuit configurations for tunable narrowband carrier aggregation in the UHF segment of TV White Spaces, antenna configurations for supporting polarization diversity in MIMO-based DSA, optimized price-based cognitive MIMO (CMIMO) precoders whose design was inspired by game theoretic interference mitigation and power allocation techniques, and scheduling mechanisms for network-wide CMIMO operation. Optimizations at both the signal level (via MIMO precoding matrices) as well as the antenna level (via highly tunable small form-factor reconfigurable antennas) were performed.

More specifically, the PIs completed the design, fabrication, and testing of a reconfigurable ultra-wide band (UWB) MIMO antenna for cognitive radio applications. The antenna supports a 11.5-to-1 bandwidth ratio, operating over a frequency range from 430 MHz to 5 GHz. It uses two independent paths (RF chains), where the first path connects directly to the UWB antenna (for 1-5 GHz range) while the other path covers frequencies from 430 MHz to 1 GHz. For the second path, a DC-controlled varactor was used for the matching network. The switching functionality between the wideband region (1 to 5 GHz) and the reconfigurable region (430 MHz to 1 GHz) was realized using two discrete switches. The designed antenna has a simple structure and compact size of 60-by-100 mm. Simulation results and experimental testing indicate that the proposed design is a good candidate for cognitive radio applications.

On the theory/algorithmic side, the PIs designed several power control mechanisms for a network of devices (multiple peer-to-peer links), each equipped with the MIMO reconfigurable antenna. Considering a wiretap channel model where the receiver (Rx) is equipped with full-duplex capability to suppress self-interference due to its own friendly jamming signal, the PIs aimed at maximizing the per-link secrecy rate by optimizing the assigned powers (or antenna weights) both for the information as well as friendly jamming signals. A joint optimization problem was formulated for the transmit (Tx) powers (including information plus friendly jamming MIMO signals from the Tx) and Rx friendly jamming signal. Because of the nonconvexity of the problem, the PIs provided lower bounds on the power allocated for Tx friendly jamming, above which positive rate secrecy is achievable. Once positive secrecy was achieved, the secrecy rate becomes monotonically increasing in the power at the transmitter. Despite its suboptimality, such an approach precludes the possibility of employing successive interference cancellation by eavesdropping devices, hence degrading their ability to intercept ongoing communications. The Rx friendly jamming power assignment (PA) of any given link was adjusted using an on-off PA that depends only on the link’s local channel state information (CSI). With every link following such a strategy, the PIs modeled this interaction as a noncooperative game and derived sufficient conditions for the uniqueness of the resulting Nash equilibrium. The PIs then proposed an algorithm to implement the PA game. Lastly, the PIs relaxed knowledge of eavesdropper’s CSI (E-CSI) and proposed a framework that is robust to unknown E-CSI. Results indicate that this robust framework performs close to when E-CSI is fully known to legitimate links. Moreover, empirically the PIs showed that the secrecy sum-rate scales with the power budget of transmitters.

The project fulfilled several educational and outreach objectives. It provided opportunities for training and professional development to several Ph.D. and M.S. students (four of the students were females). One student who was supported by this project joined academia as a tenure-track faculty; several others assumed positions at leading industry. Results from this project were integrated into the curricula of undergraduate and graduate courses.  The project resulted in 7 Ph.D. dissertations, two M.S. theses, over 40 peer-reviewed publications in top international conferences and high-impact journals, and several granted patents. The project results were broadly disseminated through publications and also via numerous presentations in conferences, research colloquia, and university seminars.
